{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3675752,"name":"Julius","username":"JuliusMDevav","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/839c29/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T01:52:22.251Z","cooked":"

I always seem to be going back and forth between how I name my variables. Whether I have it be a very clear yet unnecessarily long name for the variable/command, or a 2 letter abrevation. Which is better? Which do you guys use? Especially working in a team environment is kinda annoying when you don‚Äôt know what variables are what when you didn‚Äôt program the subsystem yourself.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T01:52:22.251Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":435,"readers_count":434,"score":187.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Julius","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76231,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675777,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T01:57:30.473Z","cooked":"

Picking names for variables is like picking notes when improvising in Jazz. No wrong names, no wrong notes. There‚Äôs choices, and then there‚Äôs better choices.

Naming internal things in software is an exercise in communication - between you and your teammates, and between you and your future self.

Names need to be easily understood, so the team isn‚Äôt wasting time to decipher meaning.

Long names help with this, but take a while to type (and often have redundant information in them).

Ultimately, what works well for team of programmers might not work well for others. It‚Äôs important to workshop these expectations with team members so they start on a similar page.

A similar exercise happens when another person code-reviews changes - this forces at least two people to agree that the naming patterns make sense, which is a much better guarantee that the name is good than just one person picking the name.

And really, rather than any naming pattern or standard, that‚Äôs what I recommend:

  1. Workshop some examples with the whole programming team before the season starts. See what the like, what they hate, and what they don‚Äôt care about.
  2. Do more code reviews in-season. If the other person can‚Äôt derive a variable‚Äôs intent from its name right after it was written, take the time to build consensus on what would be meaningful, and change it right there.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T02:31:05.960Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":361,"readers_count":360,"score":122.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52943,"username":"Jimmyy","name":"Jimmy McCosker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jimmyy/{size}/199505_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675831,"name":"Rhett Adam","username":"rhettadam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rhettadam/{size}/267138_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T02:43:06.852Z","cooked":"

I always follow the philosophy of long variable names in snake-case format when programming my personal projects. Even though no-one else is collaborating on the same project, I still prefer it to be readable to my future self. Short variable names might save you a few seconds of typing or milliseconds of compute time, but ultimately, for the the sake of yourself and others, use readable, sequential variable names.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T02:43:06.852Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":338,"readers_count":337,"score":97.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Rhett Adam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55650,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7525 Mentor | peekorobo.com"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675843,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T02:57:05.656Z","cooked":"

The following is just general advice, and you will encounter situations in which you have to break some of the rules below. That said, here are some helpful principles; note that many of them overlap:

  • Name things after what they do, rather than what they are.
    • It‚Äôs tempting to put type information in variable names (e.g. FooMap, FooArray, FooSubsystem, but with modern tooling it‚Äôs usually really easy to see what type something is, so this is just clutter.
    • Similarly, it‚Äôs usually not very helpful to name things after design patterns (e.g. FooFactory, FooStrategy). If you‚Äôve implemented the design pattern well, it‚Äôll be apparent from the shape of the API contract along with (hopefully well-chosen) semantic names what the pattern is.
  • Name things after what they do, rather than how they do it.
    • As prototype code expands you often develop a number of closely-related functions or variables with variants of the same name, distinguished by small implementation details (which, consequently, leak into the names). If these names reach the public API, they can easily become an abstraction leakage; and even if they do not, they become a distraction for anyone approaching the library for the first time.
    • When you notice this happening, consider de-duplicating the function definitions with a generic function taking a configuration parameter specifying the implementation details. This way, you can control the degree of abstraction-leakage explicitly and without generating namespace pollution.
  • Try to use names from the audience‚Äôs problem-space, rather than the author‚Äôs solution-space.
    • Writing code isn‚Äôt any different than writing any other language - you have to know who your audience is, and write for that audience. Names that are convenient for you while you are writing the program, may not be convenient for the user while they are using the program; nor for the maintainer when they are fixing the program.
    • These different audiences require separate consideration, and often you will want to use different standards for naming in different parts of your code depending on who you expect to be reading each part. It is normal and healthy for public API handles exposed to the end user to have somewhat different naming than deep internals.
  • Use shorter names for locals than for globals.
    • There‚Äôs always a duality between the amount of information in the context around a name, and the amount of information in the name. By nature, locals are extremely contextual; so, by the same token, they don‚Äôt need as much info in the name as a global does.
    • Hard rules like ‚Äúnever use a single-letter variable name‚Äù are dumb; local dummy variables in functional parameters or control structures are often most convenient as single characters.
","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T03:01:17.498Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":338,"readers_count":337,"score":417.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":20},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675850,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T03:43:24.996Z","cooked":"
Oblarg:

Try to use names from the audience‚Äôs problem-space, rather than the author‚Äôs solution-space

This is a lot like the XY problem for variable naming (and is great advice).

As for whether short or long variable names should be used, my preference is to correlate a variable‚Äôs scope with how much work I put into choosing a lengthy name. I‚Äôll use long, descriptive names for public fields, methods, and parameter names in said public methods, but I‚Äôll also let myself use shorter names for variables with smaller scope. Private fields and parameters for private methods are a bit of a middleground to me, but I err on the side of longer names because really, it‚Äôs unlikely you‚Äôre ever going to type out the whole variable name more than twice if you have a reasonably modern editor, so it comes at very little cost to the programmer.

One more note: I find that WPILib is a good example of naming done right. I often find myself perusing its source code, and I think the WPILib devs do a great job at naming variables (among plenty other things but those don‚Äôt correlate to this thread).

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T03:43:24.996Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":293,"readers_count":292,"score":103.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XY_problem","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"XY problem - Wikipedia","clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead - 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675918,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T12:50:03.736Z","cooked":"

If i can hear myself typing for more than a quarter second the name is too long and i will shorten it to the first letters if each word in it. For int iterators i go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T12:50:03.736Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":251,"readers_count":250,"score":100.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL Creator & Maintainer"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3675921,"name":"Drew Williams","username":"jreneew2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jreneew2/{size}/135239_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T12:57:26.529Z","cooked":"

Use a linter / formatter that will take care of the casing for you.

For actual names, I like to be as descriptive as possible given the scope of the variable. We aren‚Äôt limited to super small screens so there isn‚Äôt a reason to make super short variable names.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T12:57:26.529Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":78.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Drew Williams","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21777,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":" 2053 Head Mentor "},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676005,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T15:25:35.633Z","cooked":"
nstrike:

For int iterators i go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k

This statement intrigued me‚Ä¶ why that order specifically? I‚Äôm used to simply i/j/k for nested iterators, so I‚Äôm curious where v/g/h comes in for you.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T15:25:35.633Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":93.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/12","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676006,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T15:27:54.593Z","cooked":"

It comes from a very cursed time and place‚Ä¶.

As for that order, its just my preference. Stemming from for i,v in dict

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T15:27:54.593Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":206,"readers_count":205,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL Creator & Maintainer"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/13","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676028,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T16:08:02.950Z","cooked":"

Ah okay, got it. For map/dict iteration, I usually use k,v (for key/value). If it‚Äôs a numerically-indexed array, then i,v could definitely make sense as well. I definitely wouldn‚Äôt use I then v (etc) for nested loop indexes/iterators, but I can see the thought process

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T16:08:02.950Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":202,"readers_count":201,"score":70.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/14","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676043,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T16:39:30.283Z","cooked":"

For integer loop control variables that have a weak meaning, I use i, j, k, m, and n (skipping l because it looks like a 1 in Courier and other typewriter based fonts). In MATLAB, I will start with j because I use the built in i from time to time for \sqrt{-1}. Of course, if I‚Äôm looping over rows and columns, I may well use row and col. For iteration over strings and other objects with a weak meaning, I usually go with a, b, c, ‚Ä¶ .
I totally agree with these 3 from @oblarg:

Oblarg:
  • Name things after what they do, rather than how they do it.
  • Try to use names from the audience‚Äôs problem-space, rather than the author‚Äôs solution-space.
  • Use shorter names for locals than for globals.

I don‚Äôt get this one. I hope I just misunderstand what you‚Äôre saying:

Oblarg:
  • Name things after what they do, rather than what they are.

I get this for methods, function handles, and the like which should usually be verbs, but are you suggesting naming the drivetrain object MoveTheRobotAround and a manipulator HandleTheGamePiece?

‚ÄúDrive‚Äù is a perfectly fine name for the thing that drives the robot. Most natural languages are very flexible about parts-of-speech; you can ‚Äúnoun‚Äù a verb, or ‚Äúverb‚Äù a noun.

There‚Äôs one in the original post, I think?

If you have a local array of subsystems and you‚Äôre tempted to name it subsystemArray, maybe rethink that. We know it‚Äôs an array of subsystems immediately on mouseover; that name tells us nothing.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T17:07:37.461Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":130.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"Nathan Zhou","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinyin","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pinyin - Wikipedia","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Fennekinü¶ä is so cute!"},"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/19","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676060,"name":"GaryVoshol","username":"GaryVoshol","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/garyvoshol/{size}/1658_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T17:10:47.562Z","cooked":"
nstrike:

For int iterators i go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k

Us old FORTRAN coders (there are a few around) are cringing because some of those choices aren‚Äôt ‚Äúreal‚Äù integer variable names.

Don‚Äôt do what one of my colleagues had to try to unravel. Someone programmed in FORTRAN who didn‚Äôt really know FORTRAN. They knew BASIC. So every variable name was 1 or 2 characters long: t, tt, t1, t2, ‚Ä¶ all had something to do with time. It was so hard to follow that she gave up and rewrote it completely.

So I agree with many other posts, make variable names longer and descriptive.

","post_number":20,"post_type":1,"posts_count":32,"updated_at":"2025-07-07T17:10:47.562Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":55.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504011,"topic_slug":"programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables","display_username":"GaryVoshol","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"FLL and FRC Volunteer","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":5172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/programmers-how-do-you-name-your-variables/504011/20","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3676064,"name":"Justin Nesselrotte","username":"jnesselr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jnesselr/{size}/199903_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-07T17:13:06.856Z","cooked":"

I agree wholeheartedly with these suggestions and wanted to add a couple of extra additions on the audience problem space one, since I have found that to be the hardest to think about when you‚Äôre a more junior dev. (Not that more senior devs have perfectly nailed this either )

  • Try to make your class names build out thoughts. For example, a runIntake with a true or false parameter named run is probably an anti-pattern. Your parameter somewhat contradicts the name of the class and a reader has to understand later that runIntake(false) actually means to stop the intake. Whereas if your subsystem has runIntake and stopIntake, then you‚Äôre building out the neural connection that the subsystem has the ability to ‚Äúrun‚Äù and to ‚Äústop‚Äù. If the subsystem is an ‚ÄúIntake‚Äù, then you could even shorten them to run and to stop. But if the user has to stop and think ‚Äúwhat am I running‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat am I stopping‚Äù, then you‚Äôve probably shortened it too much. Remember that you always have more context writing it the first time than reading it.
  • On the note of ‚Äúsimple‚Äù variable types as parameters, such as true/false, integers, etc. Many IDEs now will actually show you what parameter name is being filled in if you put in a simple type into a parameter. The called code parameter name is based on the context inside the method and how it will be used, but that may not always define why I as the calling code want to give a particular variable name. There‚Äôs no harm in putting an extra boolean whatINeedThisBooleanFor = true above and using the variable name. The compiler will more or less not care in any noticeable way.
  • Refactor for understanding. You might be afraid to refactor your code if it‚Äôs working, but it‚Äôs always useful to refactor code if you don‚Äôt understand it. If you‚Äôre using a version control system like git (and you should be), it‚Äôs easy enough to revert your changes as you develop your understanding. It might be useful to realize that the name of a variable would have been clearer if it were changed or if a comment were added. You should feel empowered to add those clarifications in the code.
  • For some light reading, check out ‚ÄúDomain Driven Design‚Äù and the thoughts around ‚ÄúUbiquitous Language‚Äù.
